text:
*Chapter 2: Conversation and Computers* (pages 13-25)
<https://mitpress.mit.edu/9780262140539/a-small-matter-of-programming/|A Small Matter of Programming by Bonnie A. Nardi>

elements.text: A Small Matter of Programming by Bonnie A. Nardi

text:
It's pretty neat how current this book reads being published in 1993. I like Nardi's counter examples of driving cars and playing music as alternatives to natural language ("mundane conversation") as the default medium of human machine communication.

Reminds me of something I read recently in <https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/18770267-make-it-stick|Make It Stick>—that there is no empirical support for the claim that instruction in one’s preferred learning style (e.g. "I'm a visual learner") improves learning outcomes. It's the subject matter that dictates the best medium, e.g. diagrams for geometry, words for poetry

Reminds me of something I read recently in

—that there is no empirical support for the claim that instruction in one’s preferred learning style (e.g. "I'm a visual learner") improves learning outcomes. It's the subject matter that dictates the best medium, e.g. diagrams for geometry, words for poetry

text: Definitely an interesting chapter, though I struggled a bit with some of the linguistics analysis. We know now that computers are capable of mundane conversation, so I feel like there are some follow up questions worth asking

elements.text: Definitely an interesting chapter, though I struggled a bit with some of the linguistics analysis. We know now that computers are capable of mundane conversation, so I feel like there are some follow up questions worth asking

text:
Nardi seems to suggest that programs require too much precision to be described without formal semantics. But we often talk to each other about how code works (e.g. specifications aren’t written in code, but are an informal means of meta-programming).

I there agree that code is a good direct interface with the computer, but for many of the computer users who want to program but don’t know how to code, I feel that conversational model in the AI era has a lot more promise than this chapter foresaw.

I there agree that code is a good direct interface with the computer, but for many of the computer users who want to program but don’t know how to code, I feel that conversational model in the AI era has a lot more promise than this chapter foresaw.

text: Yeah, the chapter felt like the AI chapter with Nardi as the AI skeptic. I am craving a blog post or something with her thoughts 30 years later on how the chapter aged (looks like she hasn't blogged in over a decade though, so I'm not getting my hopes up haha).
